what: Error in var.relations: allvariables do not contain the candidate variables
title: Troubleshooting common issues
text: guard clause intended catch cases attempting look candidate variables included data set. Firstly, make sure candidates argument contains variables present indepedent variables x: However, using data set number-like feature identifiers, automatically coerced X<number> data frame created, causing mismatch. fix , change argument adding paste0("X", candidates). Make sure variables argument .
code: all(candidates %in% colnames(x)) # Must evaluate to TRUE

what: var.select.smd is stuck at Growing trees.. Progress
title: Troubleshooting common issues
text: output Growing trees.. made ranger large forest built. main part function however emit progress messages, causing appear stalled. can verify function still running checking CPU usage. issue especially relevant large data sets. improved since rework (Version 0.3.0). still recommended use high performance computer large amounts RAM larger data sets.

title: Surrogate Minimal Depth Variable Importance
text: R package, several functions provided applying approaches based random forest. Minimal depth (MD), Surrogate minimal depth (SMD) mutual impurity reduction (MIR), corrected approach SMD, can applied assess importance variables select important variables. addition, parameters mean adjusted agreement mutual forest impact (MFI), corrected approach previous, can applied investigate variable relations based surrogate variables. Please cite following manuscripts use package: [1] S. Seifert, S. Gundlach, S. Szymczak, Surrogate minimal depth importance measure variables random forests, Bioinformatics 2019, 35, 3663-3671. [doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btz149] [2] publication MFI/MIR preparation [arXiv Preprint]

title: Surrogate Minimal Depth Variable Importance
text: package contains example data set consists single replicate simulation study 1 publication [1]. Please refer paper documentation SMD_example_data details simulation scenario. R script simulation published .

title: Surrogate Minimal Depth Variable Importance
text: First package example data loaded: data set 100 observations rows columns contain continuous outcome variable y 200 continuous predictor variables columns.

title: Surrogate Minimal Depth Variable Importance
text: First, perform variable selection based minimal depth using 1000 trees random forest. make analysis reproducible set seed first. selected variables stored res.md$var. analysis relevant basic variables "X2" "X6", well relevant variables "cp1_8", "cp2_1", "cp2_6", "cp2_7", "cp3_4", "cp3_6", non-relevant variables "cgn_20", "cgn_68", "cgn_72", "cgn_81" selected. MD values predictor variable threshold select variables can extracted follows: can see variables "X2", …, "X6" MD values smaller threshold contrast "X1".
code: set.seed(42) res.md <- var.select.md(   x = SMD_example_data[, -1], y = SMD_example_data[, 1],    num.trees = 1000)  res.md$var # [1] "X2"     "X3"     "X4"     "X5"     "X6"     "cp1_8"  # [7] "cp2_1"  "cp2_6"  "cp2_7"  "cp3_4"  "cp3_6"  "cgn_20" # [13] "cgn_68" "cgn_72" "cgn_81" md <- res.md$info$depth head(md) #    X1    X2    X3    X4    X5    X6  # 9.743 7.907 6.155 6.615 6.456 6.428   res.md$info$threshold # [1] 9.230328

title: Surrogate Minimal Depth Variable Importance
text: Now like analyze example data surrogate minimal depth works similarly. However, need specify additional parameter s, number surrogate variables considered. analysis use s = 10. Based simulation studies recommend set parameter approximately 1% predictor variables larger datasets. Variable selection var.select.smd conducted: selected variables stored res.smd$var. analysis relevant basic variables "X1" "X6", well relevant variables "cp1_1" "cp1_10", "cp2_1", "cp2_3", "cp2_4", "cp2_6" "cp2_10", "cp3_4" selected. Compared MD relevant variables none non-relevant variables selected. SMD values predictor variable threshold select variables can extracted follows: can see variables "X1", …, "X6" SMD values smaller threshold.
code: set.seed(42) res.smd <- var.select.smd(   x = SMD_example_data[, -1], y = SMD_example_data[, 1],    s = 10, num.trees = 1000)  res.smd$var #  [1] "X1"     "X2"     "X3"     "X4"     "X5"     "X6"     #  [7] "X7"     "X8"     "cp1_1"  "cp1_2"  "cp1_3"  "cp1_4"  # [13] "cp1_5"  "cp1_6"  "cp1_7"  "cp1_8"  "cp1_9"  "cp1_10" # [19] "cp2_1"  "cp2_3"  "cp2_4"  "cp2_6"  "cp2_7"  "cp2_9"  # [25] "cp2_10" "cp3_4" smd = res.smd$info$depth head(smd) #    X1    X2    X3    X4    X5    X6  # 2.112 2.085 1.806 2.208 2.148 2.014   res.smd$info$threshold # [1] 2.671644

what: Variable relations based on the mean adjusted agreement of surrogate variables
title: Surrogate Minimal Depth Variable Importance
text: Now want investigate relations variables. like identify first 100 predictor variables related "X1" "X7". simulated 10 correlated predictor variables two basic variables. One possibility investigate variable relations use results var.select.smd(). Hence, first SMD conducted like previous section. Subsequently, variable relations analyzed var.relations(). parameter t can adapted either focus strongly related variables (high numbers) include also moderately related variables (low numbers): variables correlated "X1" correctly identified related "X1" variables correlated "X7" correctly identified related "X7".
code: candidates <- colnames(SMD_example_data)[2:101] rel <- var.relations(   forest = res.smd$forest,    variables = c("X1", "X7"), candidates = candidates,    t = 5)  rel$var # $X1 #  [1] "cp1_1"  "cp1_2"  "cp1_3"  "cp1_4"  "cp1_5"  "cp1_6"  #  [7] "cp1_7"  "cp1_8"  "cp1_9"  "cp1_10" #  # $X7 #  [1] "cp7_1"  "cp7_2"  "cp7_3"  "cp7_4"  "cp7_5"  "cp7_6"  #  [7] "cp7_7"  "cp7_8"  "cp7_9"  "cp7_10"

what: Variable relations based on Mutual Forest Impact (MFI)
title: Surrogate Minimal Depth Variable Importance
text: MFI corrected relation parameter calculated mean adjusted agreement variables permuted versions . Related variables selected p-values obtained null distribution either determined negative relation scores (based Janitza approach) permuted relations. use default parameters selection , p-values threshold 0.01 Janitza approach. Also MFI, variables correlated "X1" correctly identified related "X1" variables correlated "X7" correctly identified related "X7". Also matrix determined relation (surr.res), permuted relations (surr.perm) determined p-values (p.rel) can extracted follows:
code: set.seed(42) rel.mfi <- var.relations.mfi(   x = SMD_example_data[, -1], y = SMD_example_data[, 1],    s = 10, num.trees = 1000, variables = c("X1","X7"),   candidates = colnames(SMD_example_data)[2:101],    p.t = 0.01, method = "janitza", num.threads = 1)  rel.mfi$var.rel # $X1 #  [1] "cp1_1"  "cp1_2"  "cp1_3"  "cp1_4"  "cp1_5"  "cp1_6"  #  [7] "cp1_7"  "cp1_8"  "cp1_9"  "cp1_10" #  # $X7 #  [1] "cp7_1"  "cp7_2"  "cp7_3"  "cp7_4"  "cp7_5"  "cp7_6"  #  [7] "cp7_7"  "cp7_8"  "cp7_9"  "cp7_10" MFI <- rel.mfi$surr.res surr.perm <- rel.mfi$surr.perm p.rel <- rel.mfi$p.rel

title: Surrogate Minimal Depth Variable Importance
text: Now like analyze example data MIR, determines variable importance actual impurity reduction combined relations determined MFI. Different MD SMD, approach calculates p-values selection important variables. , null distribution obtained similar way MFI, either negative importance scores called Janitza approach permutation. Since example data set comparatively small, use permutation approach. threshold selection value 0.01 applied (p.t.sel = 0.01). selected variables stored res.mir$var. , relevant variables "cp1_1" "cp1_10", "cp2_1", "cp2_3", "cp2_4", "cp2_6", "cp2_7", "cp2_10", "cp3_1", "cp3_4", "cp3_5", well non-relevant variables "cgn_72" "cgn_81" selected. MIR values p-values can extracted follows: can see variables "X1", …, "X6" p-value 0 selected. Since approach based actual impurity reduction combined relations determined MFI, can also extracted results: res.mfi contains results var.relations.mfi() conducted MIR.
code: set.seed(42) res.mir <- var.select.mir(   x = SMD_example_data[, -1], y = SMD_example_data[, 1],    s = 10, num.trees = 1000, method.sel = "permutation",   p.t.sel = 0.01, num.threads = 1)  res.mir$var #  [1] "X1"     "X2"     "X3"     "X4"     "X5"     "X6"     #  [7] "cp1_1"  "cp1_2"  "cp1_3"  "cp1_4"  "cp1_5"  "cp1_6"  # [13] "cp1_7"  "cp1_8"  "cp1_9"  "cp1_10" "cp2_1"  "cp2_3"  # [19] "cp2_4"  "cp2_6"  "cp2_7"  "cp2_10" "cp3_1"  "cp3_4"  # [25] "cp3_5"  "cgn_72" "cgn_81" mir <- res.mir$info$MIR  head(mir) #       X1       X2       X3       X4       X5       X6  # 10.68243 15.95674 27.09036 20.50233 23.16293 21.15731  pvalues <- res.mir$info$pvalue  head(pvalues) # X1 X2 X3 X4 X5 X6  #  0  0  0  0  0  0 air <- res.mir$info$AIR  head(air) #        X1        X2        X3        X4        X5        X6  #  1.072849 13.133904 26.444900 19.155187 22.718355 20.782305    res.mfi <- res.mir$info$relations

what: Example data set for the package SurrogateMinimalDepth — SMD_example_data
title: Example data set for the package SurrogateMinimalDepth — SMD_example_data
text: dataset containing 100 individuals (rows), 1 dependent variable (first column, y), 200 additional variables (columns 2 201): simulation 200 additional variables nine variables X1,…,X9 called basic variables simulated. X1 X6 causal constant effect sizes 1 X7 X9 noncausal effect size 0. outcome y linear combination causal predictor variables normally distributed error term. basic variables sampled normal distribution (N(0,1)) just like noise (N(0,0.2)). six basic variables X1, X2, X3, X7, X8, X9 ten variables predefined correlations 0.9 X1 X7, 0.6 X2 X8, 0.3 X3 X9 obtained simulateModule function R package WGCNA. ten variables basis variable labeled: Cp_basicvariable_number. Additional non-correlated independent predictor variables (cgn) simulated using standard normal distribution reach total number 200 variables.

title: Add layer information to a forest that was created by getTreeranger — addLayer
text: list tree data frames length RF$num.trees. row tree data frames corresponds node respective tree columns correspond : nodeID: ID respective node (important left right daughters next columns) leftdaughter: ID left daughter node rightdaughter: ID right daughter node splitvariable: ID split variable splitpoint: Split point split variable. categorical variables comma separated lists values, representing factor levels (original order) going right. status: 0 terminal (splitpoint NA) 1 non-terminal. layer: Tree layer depth information, starting 0 (root node) incremented layer.

text: list trees. list trees containing lists nodes elements: nodeID: ID respective node (important left right daughters next columns) leftdaughter: ID left daughter node rightdaughter: ID right daughter node splitvariable: ID split variable splitpoint: splitpoint split variable status: 0 terminal 1 non-terminal layer: layer information (0 means root node, 1 means 1 layer root, etc) surrogate_i: numbered surrogate variables (number depending s) adj_i: adjusted agreement variable

title: Apply cluster analysis to build variable groups — build.clusters
code: # read data data("SMD_example_data")  # \donttest{ # get trees and variable names x <- SMD_example_data[, 2:ncol(SMD_example_data)] y <- SMD_example_data[, 1] allvariables <- colnames(x) # extract variables names nvar <- length(allvariables) # count number of variables set.seed(42) RF <- ranger::ranger(   data = SMD_example_data,   dependent.variable.name = "y",   num.trees = 10,   keep.inbag = TRUE,   mtry = floor(nvar^(3 / 4)),   min.node.size = 1,   num.threads = 1 ) trees <- getTreeranger(RF = RF, num.trees = 10) trees.lay <- addLayer(trees) trees.surr <- addSurrogates(RF = RF, trees = trees.lay, s = 10, Xdata = x, num.threads = 1)  # investigate variable relations rel <- var.relations(   forest = list(trees = trees.surr, allvariables = allvariables),   variables = code: # read data data("SMD_example_data") # \donttest{ ###### use result of SMD variable importance and reduce surrogate variables to 10 # select variables with smd variable importance (usually more trees are needed) set.seed(42) res <- var.select.smd(   x = as.data.frame(SMD_example_data[, 2:ncol(SMD_example_data)]),   y = SMD_example_data[, 1],   s = 100,   num.trees = 10,   num.threads = 1 ) forest.new <- reduce.surrogates(forest = res$forest, s = 10)  # execute SMD on tree with reduced number of surrogates res.new <- var.select.smd(   forest = forest.new,   num.threads = 1 ) res.new$var #>  [1] "X2"      "X3"      "X4"      "X5"      "X6"      "X8"      "cp1_1"   #>  [8] "cp1_4"   "cp1_5"   "cp1_6"   "cp1_8"   "cp1_9"   "cp2_2"   "cp2_3"   #> [15] "cp2_4"   "cp2_5"   "cp2_10"  "cp3_3"   "cp3_4"   "cp3_5"   "cp3_6"   #> [22] "cp7_1"   "cp8_2"   "cp8_5"   "cgn_4"   "cgn_19"  "cgn_47"  "cgn_49"  #> [29] "cgn_62"  "cgn_75"  "cgn_121"  #' # investigate variable relations rel <- var.relations(   forest = forest.new,   variables = c("X1", "X7"),   candidates = res$forest[["allvariables"]][1:100],   t = 5,   num.threads = 1 ) rel$var #> $X1 #>  [1] "cp1_1"  "cp1_2"  "cp1_3"  "cp1_4"  "cp1_5"  "cp1_6"  "cp1_7"  "cp1_8"  #>  [9] "cp1_9"  "cp1_10" "cp8_1"  #>  #> $X7 #>  [1] "cp7_1"  "cp7_2"  "cp7_3"  "cp7_4"  "cp7_5"  "cp7_6"  "cp7_7"  "cp7_8"  #>  [9] "cp7_9"  "cp7_10" #>  # }

title: Variable selection with Surrogate Minimal Depth (SMD) (MAIN FUNCTION) — var.select.smd
text: x data.frame predictor variables variables columns samples rows (Note: missing values allowed) y vector values phenotype variable (Note: converted factor classification mode used). survival forests time variable. num.trees number trees. Default 500. type mode prediction ("regression", "classification" "survival"). Default regression. s predefined number surrogate splits (may happen actual number surrogate splits differs individual nodes). Default 1 % . variables. mtry number variables possibly split node. Default . variables^(3/4) ("^3/4") recommended (Ishwaran 2011). Also possible "sqrt" "0.5" use square root half . variables. min.node.size minimal node size. Default 1. num.threads number threads used parallel execution. Default number CPUs available. status status variable, applicable survival data. Use 1 event 0 censoring. save.ranger set TRUE ranger object saved. Default ranger object saved (FALSE). create.forest Default: TRUE `forest` NULL, FALSE otherwise. Whether create use existing forest. forest random forest analyzed save.memory Use memory saving (slower) splitting mode. effect survival GWAS data. Warning: option slows tree growing, use encounter memory problems. (parameter transfered ranger) case.weights Weights sampling training observations. Observations larger weights selected higher probability bootstrap (subsampled) samples trees.

title: RFSurrogates 0.3.4
text: create.forest now defaults .null(forest), automatically TRUE forest provided, FALSE otherwise. x longer required create.forest FALSE. (Internal) Inverted nested guard clauses readability. Add num.threads param enable parallelization using parallel::mclapply(). defaults 1 backward compatability. Add num.threads param (passed mc.cores parallel::mclapply()). defaults 1 backward compatability. Add add_layer param include effect addLayer within loop. Defaults FALSE backward compatability. (Internal) getsingletree(): Add add_layer param enable adding layers within loop. Clarified default value num.threads parallel::detectCores() adding default parameter Added assertion RF ranger object. Added assertion RF$num.trees length(trees) equal. considered breaking change since values always equal function used correctly. getTreeranger() now returns RangerTrees list. addLayer() getTreeranger(add_layer = TRUE) add LayerTrees class list (indicating presence layer list item). now requires trees param inherits RangerTrees. addSurrogates() now adds SurrogateTrees class. now requires trees param inherits RangerTrees.
